"**Wish You Were Here** " is the title track on [Pink Floyd](/wiki/Pink_Floyd
"Pink Floyd")'s 1975 album _[Wish You Were
Here](/wiki/Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_album\) "Wish You Were Here \(Pink
Floyd album\)")_.[1][2] [David Gilmour](/wiki/David_Gilmour "David Gilmour")
and [Roger Waters](/wiki/Roger_Waters "Roger Waters") collaborated to write
the music, and Gilmour sang the lead vocal.

In 2011, the song was ranked No. 324 on [Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of
All Time](/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "Rolling
Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time").[3]

##
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Composition")]

In the original album version, the song [segues](/wiki/Segue "Segue") from
"[Have a Cigar](/wiki/Have_a_Cigar "Have a Cigar")" as if a radio had been
tuned away from one station, through several others (including a radio play
and one playing the opening of the finale movement of
[Tchaikovsky](/wiki/Tchaikovsky "Tchaikovsky")'s [Fourth
Symphony](/wiki/Symphony_No._4_\(Tchaikovsky\) "Symphony No. 4
\(Tchaikovsky\)")), and finally to a new station where "Wish You Were Here" is
beginning.[4] The radio was recorded from Gilmour's car radio. He performed
the intro on a [twelve-string guitar](/wiki/Twelve-string_guitar "Twelve-
string guitar"), processed to sound like it was playing through an AM radio,
and then overdubbed a fuller-sounding acoustic guitar solo. This passage was
mixed to sound as though a guitarist were listening to the radio and playing
along. As the acoustic part becomes more complex, the 'radio broadcast' fades
away and Gilmour's voice enters, becoming joined by the full band.[5]

The intro riff is repeated several times, before Gilmour plays further solos
with [scat singing](/wiki/Scat_singing "Scat singing") accompaniment. A third
verse follows, featuring an increasingly expressive vocal from Gilmour and
audible backing vocals. At the end of the recorded song, the final solo
[crossfades](/wiki/Crossfader "Crossfader") with wind sound effects, and
finally segues into the second section of the multi-part suite "[Shine On You
Crazy Diamond](/wiki/Shine_On_You_Crazy_Diamond "Shine On You Crazy
Diamond")".

Lyrically, the song is often considered to be a direct tribute to [Syd
Barrett](/wiki/Syd_Barrett "Syd Barrett"). However, on the documentary _[The
Story of Wish You Were Here](/wiki/The_Story_of_Wish_You_Were_Here "The Story
of Wish You Were Here")_ , Gilmour and Waters separately describe the original
concept that differs from this interpretation. Waters, who mainly wrote the
lyrics complementing Gilmour's initial riff idea and subsequent joint
composition, describes the lyrics as being directed at himself, as his lyrics
often are. Being present in one's own life and freeing one's self in order to
truly experience life is a main topic in this song. Gilmour, on the other
hand, recognizes that he does not ever perform the song without remembering
Syd Barrett. Waters later adds that the song is nevertheless open to
interpretation.[6]

Both David Gilmour and Roger Waters have praised the song as one of Pink
Floyd's finest. Roger Waters has noted that the collaboration between himself
and David Gilmour on the song was "...really good. All bits of it are really,
really good. I'm very happy about it."[7] David Gilmour has playfully called
"Wish You Were Here" "a very simple country song" and stated that "because of
its resonance and the emotional weight it carries, it is one of our best
songs."[8]

##
Recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_song\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Recording")]

"Wish You Were Here" was recorded at [Abbey Road
Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios "Abbey Road Studios"), as part of the
sessions for the entire album.

A noted part of the song was a planned contribution by [Stéphane
Grappelli](/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Grappelli "Stéphane Grappelli"). A jazz
violinist popular at the time and well known for his collaborations with
[Yehudi Menuhin](/wiki/Yehudi_Menuhin "Yehudi Menuhin"), both violinists were
recording in a downstairs studio at Abbey Road at the time. Gilmour had
suggested that there be a little "country fiddle" at the end of the song and
invited them to participate. Grappelli duly obliged (Menuhin declined) on
arranging a session fee of £300, equivalent to £2,300 in 2018.[9] Ultimately
during mixing it was decided to almost remove his contribution, although it
can just be heard around 5:21. According to Waters it was decided that it
would be insulting to credit Grappelli in the sleeve notes for something so
inaudible, although he did receive the agreed-upon fee.[10][11][12]

As part of the _[Why Pink Floyd...?](/wiki/Why_Pink_Floyd...%3F "Why Pink
Floyd...?")_ campaign, the _Experience_ and _Immersion_ versions of the _Wish
You Were Here_ album include an alternative version of the song where
Grappelli's part is heard in the instrumental break after the second verse and
throughout the third verse before a considerably extended outro. Other less
obvious differences are audible, for example at the section leading into the
second verse.

The master tape of the original recording includes an entire performance of
pedal steel guitar and electric guitar solos, played by Gilmour, that were not
used in the final mix.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Live
performances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_song\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Live performances")]

"Wish You Were Here" made its stage debut on the band's [1977
tour](/wiki/In_the_Flesh_\(1977_Pink_Floyd_%27Animals%27_tour\) "In the Flesh
\(1977 Pink Floyd 'Animals' tour\)"), which featured a performance of the
entire album at every show. It was not played live by the band for nearly ten
years after this, yet became a concert staple after its reappearance in 1987,
and was performed at nearly all subsequent Pink Floyd concerts. In the
original 1977 concert performances, Gilmour would play his [Fender
Stratocaster](/wiki/Fender_Stratocaster "Fender Stratocaster") instead of
acoustic guitar, while [Snowy White](/wiki/Snowy_White "Snowy White") played a
twelve-string [Ovation](/wiki/Ovation_Guitar_Company "Ovation Guitar Company")
acoustic guitar. At these shows, [Nick Mason](/wiki/Nick_Mason "Nick Mason")
tuned an actual transistor radio on stage to a local radio station, seguing
into the pre-recorded part from the album to start the song and [Richard
Wright](/wiki/Richard_Wright_\(musician\) "Richard Wright \(musician\)") would
perform an extended piano coda as the wind effects played. A live version is
included on _[Pulse](/wiki/Pulse_\(Pink_Floyd_album\) "Pulse \(Pink Floyd
album\)")_. When Pink Floyd were inducted into the [Rock and Roll Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame "Rock and Roll Hall of Fame"),[13]
Gilmour and Wright (Mason was in the audience) performed the song with the
assistance of their presenter [Billy Corgan](/wiki/Billy_Corgan "Billy
Corgan") on rhythm guitar.

Gilmour has made the song a part of most of his tours, and included a live
version on his _[Live in Gdansk](/wiki/Live_in_Gdansk "Live in Gdansk")_
album.

On 13 December 2014 [David Gilmour](/wiki/David_Gilmour "David Gilmour") was a
guest performer at a concert by the [Bombay Bicycle
Club](/wiki/Bombay_Bicycle_Club "Bombay Bicycle Club") at [Earls Court
Arena](/wiki/Earl%27s_Court_Exhibition_Centre "Earl's Court Exhibition
Centre"), their concert being the final event ever to take place there before
its demolition. Band member Jamie MacColl introduced Gilmour, saying; "This
man gave me my first guitar and was one of the first people to play this venue
and by my count has played here more than 27 times." Gilmour then played with
the band on their song "Rinse Me Down" before a performance of "Wish You Were
Here".

In 2005, Waters and [Eric Clapton](/wiki/Eric_Clapton "Eric Clapton")
performed the song at the [Tsunami Aid](/wiki/Tsunami_Aid "Tsunami Aid")
concert, and in 2005's [Live 8](/wiki/Live_8 "Live 8"), Waters rejoined his
former bandmates in London to perform it, along with four other classic Pink
Floyd songs. Waters sung half the verses during Live 8, while in the original
version Gilmour did all the vocals.[14][15]

## Other recorded versions by Pink
Floyd[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_song\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Other recorded versions by Pink Floyd")]

"Wish You Were Here" appeared as the fifth track on _[A Collection of Great
Dance Songs](/wiki/A_Collection_of_Great_Dance_Songs "A Collection of Great
Dance Songs")_ in 1981 (with the radio intro following the end of a heavily
edited "Shine On You Crazy Diamond") and as the 23rd track on the
_[Echoes](/wiki/Echoes:_The_Best_of_Pink_Floyd "Echoes: The Best of Pink
Floyd")_ compilation[16] in 2001 (with the radio intro following "[Arnold
Layne](/wiki/Arnold_Layne "Arnold Layne")", and at the end crossfading with
"[Jugband Blues](/wiki/Jugband_Blues "Jugband Blues")").

A live recording included on the 1995 live album
_[P•U•L•S•E](/wiki/Pulse_\(Pink_Floyd_album\) "Pulse \(Pink Floyd album\)")_
was issued as a [single](/wiki/Single_\(music\) "Single
\(music\)")/[EP](/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play"). Its intro replicates
the sound of the original, semi-ambient intro. The cover of the EP features
two men whose faces are distorted by fish bowls, referring to the line "We're
just two lost souls swimming in a fish bowl, year after year".

"**Wish You Were Here (Live)** " is a live recording of [Pink
Floyd](/wiki/Pink_Floyd "Pink Floyd")'s title track off their ninth studio
album _[Wish You Were Here](/wiki/Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_album\)
"Wish You Were Here \(Pink Floyd album\)")_ , recorded by the band for their
third live album, _[Pulse](/wiki/Pulse_\(Pink_Floyd_album\) "Pulse \(Pink
Floyd album\)")_. "Wish You Were Here (Live)" was released as a single on 20
July 1995 in the United Kingdom and Europe, notably the very last single
released by the band until October 2014.

### Other
covers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wish_You_Were_Here_\(Pink_Floyd_song\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Other covers")]

  * British singer-songwriter [Ed Sheeran](/wiki/Ed_Sheeran "Ed Sheeran") performed a cover at the Closing Ceremonies of the London Summer Olympic Games in 2012 with [Mike Rutherford](/wiki/Mike_Rutherford "Mike Rutherford") of [Genesis](/wiki/Genesis_\(band\) "Genesis \(band\)") on guitar, [Richard Jones](/wiki/Richard_Jones_\(bassist\) "Richard Jones \(bassist\)") of [The Feeling](/wiki/The_Feeling "The Feeling") on bass, David Arnold and [Nick Mason](/wiki/Nick_Mason "Nick Mason") on drums.[28] A performer, dressed in a suit, tightrope-walked across the stadium and shook hands with a mannequin at the end, which then burst into flames, referencing the album's cover.
  * American band [Sparklehorse](/wiki/Sparklehorse "Sparklehorse") recorded a 2005 version featuring [Thom Yorke](/wiki/Thom_Yorke "Thom Yorke") of [Radiohead](/wiki/Radiohead "Radiohead").

  * American metal band [Avenged Sevenfold](/wiki/Avenged_Sevenfold "Avenged Sevenfold") covered this song on the deluxe version of their 2016 album, _[The Stage](/wiki/The_Stage_\(album\) "The Stage \(album\)")_ , along with five other covers. They perform the song live with the lead vocalist of the band [Halestorm](/wiki/Halestorm "Halestorm"), [Lzzy Hale](/wiki/Lzzy_Hale "Lzzy Hale"). [29]

  * American comedy rock duo [Ninja Sex Party](/wiki/Ninja_Sex_Party "Ninja Sex Party") covered this song on their 2016 cover album _[Under the Covers](/wiki/Under_the_Covers_\(Ninja_Sex_Party_album\) "Under the Covers \(Ninja Sex Party album\)")_ , and also produced a music video.[30]

  * The song can also be heard in the movie _[_War Dogs_ (2016 film)](/wiki/War_Dogs_\(2016_film\) "War Dogs \(2016 film\)")_. Although it has been cut from its instrumental introduction and starts directly at the first verse.

  * Ivorian singer [Alpha Blondy](/wiki/Alpha_Blondy "Alpha Blondy") included a reggae cover of Wish You Were Here on his 2007 album [Jah Victory](/wiki/Jah_Victory "Jah Victory").
